The highly conductive layer of LiBH 4 in direct contact with the oxide, whose thickness has been estimated to be about 2 nm, does not undergo a structural phase transition.
21, 26 Indeed, for samples CE74 and CE53, the calculated thicknesses of LiBH 4 are 0.4 and 1.2 nm, respectively (see Table 1 ), which are close to the values estimated in the literature.
21, 26 On the other hand, the calculated thickness of LiBH 4 for composite CE26 amounts to 3.8 nm, explaining the slight increase of the Li-ion conductivity above 110 Â°C ( Figure 1 a) and confirming that the bulk LiBH 4 contributes to the Li-ion conductivity after the phase transition.
